Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is in the field of harmonic analysis, a mathematical area that grew from the fact that many functions defined over an interval can be decomposed as sums of the simple sine and cosine functions. The principal investigator plans to study cases where such a decomposition is not possible, or is not efficient enough, for example because the functions in question are no longer defined over intervals. The question is whether similar decompositions are possible in such cases, with the sines and cosines replaced by other functions of a simple structure. The goal is to use functions that mimic the structure of the sines and cosines, in one way or another, as good replacements for the trigonometric functions, which provide an excellent tool for studying properties of functions and the interrelationships between them. In particular, this project includes the development of efficient ways to sample, interpolate, and approximate signals.

The principal investigator and collaborators have recently shown that any finite union of intervals admits a Riesz basis of exponentials. While a big advance in the area, there remain many aspects of the question that the principal investigator will study, such as clarifying whether this is a generic property of all sets of finite measure and understanding whether the result holds for Riesz bases with "good bounds." Further, she plans to study the benefits of using even weaker notions (e.g., frames, Riesz sequences) for the same purposes. Of particular interest is the relation between the study of such systems and the development of techniques to analyze sampling and interpolating sequences. Finally, the project will explore applications to Gabor systems in time-frequency analysis, for instance, possible extensions of the Balian-Low theorem and linear independence of Gabor elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this proposal was to study exponential systems and their applications to related areas of mathematics. During the time period of the project, applications to several areas of mathematics were developed, allowing the resolution of some known open problems. Below we give some of the main highlights of this work.

One such application is to the study of random Gaussian noise. Joint with Naomi Feldhein and Ohad Feldheim, the PI studied the probability that a stationary Gaussian process will remain positive over a long interval. This question has a long history, with applications to various questions in Engineering and Phisycs. However, until recently, progress was made only in very restricted cases. The PI and collaborators obtained an almost complete solution to this problem under mild regularity conditions. In a follow up work, joint also with Ben Jaye and Fedor Nazarov, a complete solution to this problem in the case where the process has a spectral gap was obtained, resolving with this a conjecture related to such processes.

In another direction, applications to the study of uncertainty principles were developed. Of particular interest were uncertainty principles related to generators of certain systems of functions. A classical such result is the Balian-Low theorem, which describes the restrictions on the time-frequency localization of generators of Gabor Riesz bases. Though it provides for an excellent ``rule of thumbs'' in time-frequency analysis, the Balian--Low theorem is not adaptable to many applications. This is due to the fact that in realistic situations, information about a signal is given by a finite dimensional vector rather then by a function over the real line. The question of whether a finite dimensional version of this theorem holds has been circling  among researchers in the area, and joint with Jan-Fredrik Olsen the PI answered this question to the affirmative.

A different, and new, machinery to study such uncertainty principles, relating them to questions regarding Fourier multipliers, was developed by the PI, Michael Northington, and Alex Powell. In another setting, an approach to study densities of sampling and interpolating sequences, discovered by the PI and Alexander Olevskii, was further developed by the PI during this time period.

This project provided also the opportunity for training of the next generation. The PI co-sponsored a postdoctoral student and advised a graduate student, both of them were incorporated into the research program associated with this project. During the projects time period the PI co-organized several conferences and AMS special sessions. This project provided the PI with the opportunity to participate in a large number of conferences, and develop both national and international collaborations.
